title: In the Storm of the Third Year of the Five Year Plan (Na shturm 3go goda piatiletka)
transcript:
MATT WITKOVKSY: Posters were the most prestigious and closely supervised mass-media art form. This is because posters were a key way to get across Soviet policy aims and ideas. They were printed in up to several hundred thousand copies at a time and plastered across the country. In the late 1920s posters by the husband-and-wife team of Gustav Klutsis and Valentina Kulagina helped to spread news of a new, state-sponsored worker ideal: the shock worker.

KATE TAHK: A shock worker is a super-productive worker. It’s a worker who exceeds their production quota by, usually, a dramatic amount. And it’s from the root of udar, which is like a blow, or “to strike,” in Russian. Udarnik. Or udarnitsa, because … women get a separate word, and there’s also female shock workers. They’re just as important.

MATT WITKOVKSY: Klutsis and Kulagina deeply understood their role as modeling ideal behavior with these posters. Slogans provided models in the sense of standards to follow or aspire to. And Klutsis and his friends actually modeled for their posters. It’s Klutsis’s own hand that we see reproduced lots of times in the poster commanding “Worker Men and Women: Everyone Vote in the Soviet Elections.” And it’s Klutsis with fellow designer Sergei Sen’kin who are the miners in the poster “The Struggle for Fuel and Metal.”
